Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:Sea level rise and vegetation regime shifts: implications for soil carbon storage and vulnerability in coastal wetlands
Award.AbstractNarration:
Coastal wetlands filter water, buffer the coastline from storms, provide important habitat and are globally important for the storage of carbon. Carbon storage in wetland soils can be for the long-term and influences whether wetlands will persist during sea level rise by increasing a change in sediment elevation. Climate change and local freshwater management are increasing the movement of saltwater into coastal freshwater wetlands, altering the conditions of the wetlands and causing shifts in the types of vegetation growing there. In many tropical and subtropical coastal wetlands, mangroves are replacing grass-dominated marshes, with uncertain effects on the capability of soils to store carbon. This is especially true of coastal wetlands, because of their sensitivity to sea level rise. The goals of this study are to identify changes in the storage of carbon in wetland soils and releases to the atmosphere of the gases carbon dioxide and methane that occur as coastal wetland change from marshes dominated by grasses to mangrove forests. The research findings will provide valuable information for the conservation and restoration of the Florida Everglades locally as well as coastal wetlands throughout the world. Furthermore, the findings will provide a broader understanding of plant and soil interactions and ecosystem function in a changing world. The project will provide hands on scientific experience identifying and growing wetland plants and restoring urban coastal wetlands for local high school students during "Marsh Mangress", an outreach activity at Florida International University. This activity will also provide undergraduate students with laboratory and field experience at a majority minority institution.

This research will utilize a vegetation gradient in 10,000 Islands National Wildlife Refuge in Naples, FL in which sea level rise and freshwater manipulation have driven vegetation change and mangrove encroachment, in order to understand how changing abiotic conditions and vegetation state change alter carbon storage through time. Changing carbon storage will be measured as current organic carbon stocks (above and belowground biomass, soil carbon content), inputs (root productivity, sediment surface accretion) and carbon losses (breakdown rates of organic carbon, gas flux measurements), past carbon sequestration rate (radiometric soil dating), and potential future rates of carbon loss (reciprocal transplant of organic matter to represent freshwater restoration or continuing saltwater intrusion). Specifically, the goals of this project are to: 1) Identify differences in carbon storage, accretion, and gas flux among wetlands dominated by brackish marsh, saltwater marsh, and mangrove-dominated vegetation communities. 2) Determine which abiotic and biotic mechanisms drive differences in soil carbon dynamics among wetland types. 3) Quantify the effect of time since mangrove establishment on soil carbon storage, accretion and gas flux by establishing a chronosequence of mangrove encroachment based on soil dating and historic aerial photography.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

            Coastal wetlands offer some of the highest levels of ecosystem services of any ecosystem type globally by providing essential habitat, improving water quality, buffering coastal communities and removing atmospheric carbon dioxide. In particular, coastal wetlands are among the most effective ecosystems at removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and storing it in plant biomass and soil organic carbon, where it can improve resilience in the face of sea-level rise. However, coastal wetlands are undergoing large changes as climate change and local water management influence saltwater intrusion, and vegetation communities shift, with uncertain impacts on ecosystem carbon storage. We addressed three main questions: 1) How do C storage, accretion, and gas flux vary among wetlands dominated by brackish marsh, saltwater marsh, mixed marsh/mangrove and mangrove-dominated vegetation communities?, 2)  What abiotic and biotic mechanisms drive differences in soil C dynamics among wetland types?, 3) How does time since mangrove establishment affect soil C storage, accretion and gas flux? 

To quantify differences in carbon stocks and fluxes, we established 3 transects that included three distinct marsh types and 6 age classes of mangroves (n = 27 sites) along an inland to coastal transect. To quantify changes within mangrove dominated sites, we used historic aerial photography to create a temporal developmental gradient from sites transitioning to mangrove vegetation to sites that have been mangrove dominated for 77-88 years. In each ecosystem type, we quantified the major carbon stocks (above and belowground biomass and soil), input rates (root productivity, surface accretion and change in aboveground biomass) and loss rates (ecosystem-specific roots and litter and standard organic matter decomposition), and measured overall soil carbon accretion over 10-, 50- and, 100-year intervals with 210Pb in a subset of sites.

We found that vegetation shifts caused by saltwater intrusion have profound impacts on carbon stocks and fluxes in coastal wetlands and that carbon storage in mangrove forests changes through time with ecosystem development. Brackish and saltmarsh contained similar levels of carbon in biomass, but soil OC was 4x higher in brackish than saltmarsh soils, indicating a significant loss of soil carbon with saltwater intrusion. Because this ecosystem carbon loss takes place belowground, it is often overlooked, but plays an essential role in ecosystem function and resilience to sea level rise. However, we found that in areas where mangroves have become established, carbon stocks are rebuilt and greatly exceed the amount of carbon stored in marsh communities as they develop through time. After 10 years of mangrove establishment, wetlands stored 10x more carbon in biomass than marshes and after 20 years, mangrove communities stored 30x more biomass aboveground and 2x more belowground. As mangroves continued to develop from 20 to more than 88 years since establishment, the carbon stored in biomass plateaued and remained the same, but soil carbon stocks continued to develop and contained 10x more soil carbon than brackish marshes after 75 years.  

Our findings quantify changes in carbon stocks and fluxes in critically important coastal wetlands undergoing vegetation shifts while facing the existential threat of sea level rise. Our findings suggest that subtropical coastal wetlands may be at peak vulnerability as marshes become saltier, but the establishment of mangroves likely increases carbon storage and resilience through time. Our study shows that facilitating inland vegetation migration may be vital to ecosystem resilience in the face of sea-level rise, identifies vulnerable ecosystems and identifies mangrove ecosystem development as a vital carbon storage mechanism.

 

Broader Impacts:

 The Florida Everglades and the Ten Thousand Islands National Wildlife Reserve represent the largest wilderness area East of the Mississippi and the largest contiguous tract of protected mangrove forest in the Western Hemisphere, but the ecosystem and the services it provides to society are largely underappreciated among urban and suburban Miami and Naples, FL. The low-lying Everglades is at the frontline of sea-level rise as well as home to the largest restoration project in the world, making this an ideal ecosystem to study the impacts of saltwater intrusion with global implications and applications. We disseminated our research discoveries through presentations at professional meetings attended by regional and national/international scientific communities. In addition, we used data from this research to create a lesson plan for high school students in collaboration with a local high school teacher. We implemented this lesson to students and developed a lesson for distribution through an NSF Data Nugget (http://datanuggets.org/). In addition, we provided five undergraduate students from underrepresented groups (four Hispanic students, one African American student) with training, science experience and part-time employment or class credit through this project. Two of our undergraduate trainees have pursued scientific disciplines in graduate school. We also recruited a visiting postbaccalaureate scientist funded through the German government as an intern, and she is currently in a Ph.D. program in Germany. We collaborated on an international decomposition experiment (ILTER TeaComposition Initiative).
